title: I am a very slow reader because my comprehension is very low.  How do I improve my reading speed and how many months to take improve my reading speed? - Quora

response.answer_text: Friend, You are not alone. The cool thing is that, unlike many people, you’ve chosen to ask this question and seek ways to improve. Reading was one of my favorite things growing up. After suffering severe brain injuries in a car accident, my ability to read was severely compromised. In elementary school, I read as a college student. At college age, I read as an elementary student. How do you fix it? WORK. Read everything. All the time. If you don’t understand a word, look it up. Take classes on grammar so that you understand what all these little punctuation marks actually mean. Sometimes, understanding what someone is saying is a product of understanding “how” they’re saying it. If you can’t look up a word, look for context clues. If an author calls something “atrocious” and goes on to talk about how bad it is - or why it’s so bad, that gives you a hint. Atrocious isn’t good. When I don’t understand a word, but I don’t want to stop reading, I write it in the margin and look it up when I’m done with that chapter. So. There’s some tips for improvement. Good luck! (By the way, I recovered my reading ability and went on to get honors degrees. I think I read better now than I did before my injuries.)

Visit the johnson o’connor institute website and take advantage of the vocabulary resources Johnson O'Connor Research Foundation you’re right! slow reading is typically a function of low comprehension. believe it or not, your comprehension can improve as your reading speed improves.There are two things holding you back. Vocabulary - lack of familiarity with words slows you down a lot. by builiding your vocabulary you will avoid the problem of words you don’t know or recognize slowing you down.. Subvocalization - a bad habit is deveped in the primary grades when the teachers ask students to read out loud. We learn to vocalize what we read. you can’t speak faster than about 250/ wpm. the result is that because many of us subvocalize, our reading speed is capped by our talking speed. you can unlearn subvocalizing by forcing your self to say nonsense words while you read. essentially you simply talk outloud any nonsense words (lalalalala) or whatever to ‘break’ the habit of talking to your self while you read. over time, the connection between your eyes and your vocal chords is broken freeing your eyes and mind up to safely read above your talking speed. I took Evelyn Wood in college and still read comfortably over 1000 wpm.
